about.title: Meet Dr. Simon Tanguay
about.subtitle: Chiropractor
about.story: After a life-changing 40-foot fall shattered his Olympic taekwondo dreams and left him in chronic pain, Dr Simon dedicated himself to uncovering pain solutions that truly work.
about.experience: For over 20 years, he has helped Montreal patients find lasting relief by addressing the true causes of pain.
about.approach: His approach examines three critical areas: how your body moves and compensates (biomechanical), internal healing factors (biochemical), and stress patterns (emotional).
about.philosophy: Dr. Simon believes in true patient empowerment — working with you to uncover and address why your pain persists and providing the tools you need to make and maintain your progress.
about.conviction: His conviction is that your pain isn't random — it's a puzzle waiting to be solved.

questions.question: Why am I still in pain?
questions.answer:
Pain is your body's warning that something isn't working properly.

Here's what actually happens when you get hurt: Your body doesn't completely heal injuries—it patches them with scar tissue, then creates workarounds to keep you moving pain-free. This masks the real problem.

When you first get injured, your body is remarkably good at compensating. It alters your movement patterns and recruits different muscles to take over for the damaged ones. This keeps you pain-free initially, but the original problem remains—it's just hidden.

The problem with compensation: Your body can only maintain these workarounds for so long. Eventually, it exhausts its ability to compensate. When these backup systems fail, chronic pain emerges—sometimes in a completely different location from the original injury.

Why finding the real cause is so difficult: That back pain you're feeling? It could actually stem from an old ankle injury that altered your walking pattern, which disrupted your pelvic motion, which then affected your spine. This chain reaction typically develops over months or even years.

Your situation may be more complex if:
• You've tried multiple treatments without success → This often means the source is deeply hidden.
• You've been in pain for a long time → This suggests it has created compensatory secondary problems.
• You have old injuries or compensation patterns that went untreated → Each one accumulates local damage.
• You experience pain in multiple areas of your body → This often indicates an underlying metabolic condition (like inflammation or immune problems).

How we approach your pain:
We view your entire body as an interconnected system. We trace back to identify where things first went wrong, then address as many of the main hidden causes at the source of your pain.

questions.question: How many sessions do I need?
questions.answer:
Recovery time varies based on your unique situation. Some patients experience noticeable relief after their first visit, while others need more time to address the underlying issues slowing their healing and recovery.

Factors that influence your healing timeline:
• Cause – How easy or difficult it is to find and target the main cause among the many hidden problems causing your pain?
• Severity and complexity – Simple vs. complex conditions – whether issues are composed of multiple layers.
• Duration – How recent your problem occurred (acute) versus chronic issues lasting months/years (which take longer to reverse).
• Health history – Past injuries, traumas, and lifestyle factors.
• Your body's healing capacity – Age, fitness level, overall health, and metabolic state.
• Lifestyle factors – Your nutrition, activity level, sleep quality, stress management, and physical demands on your body.

Typical Treatment Timelines:
• Recent acute pain (days to weeks): 3–6 sessions
Examples: Simple neck strain, new back pain

• Moderate problems (1–6 months): 8–12 sessions
Examples: Recurring headaches, ongoing back stiffness

• Chronic conditions (6+ months): 15–25+ sessions
Examples: Long-term neck/back pain, complex spine issues

questions.question: What is Chiropractic?
questions.answer:
Chiropractic is a type of healthcare focused on your spine and nervous system, which controls everything in your body. When spinal joints get stuck or misaligned, they interfere with nerve communication, causing pain and health problems.

Chiropractors restore proper movement and alignment with a chiropractic adjustment—a precise, controlled hand (or instrument) movement applied to specific joints that have become restricted in their movement. This helps restore proper joint motion and position, enhancing your body's natural ability to heal itself, without drugs or surgery.

Modern chiropractic care extends far beyond adjustments. It can include:
• Spinal & Joint Adjustments – Core intervention supported by evidence for low back pain, neck pain, and headaches
• Soft tissue therapies – massage, trigger point therapy, and myofascial release
• Therapeutic exercises – rehabilitation and strengthening programs
• Lifestyle counseling – posture, ergonomics, nutrition, and stress management
• Applied Kinesiology testing – using muscle testing and pain indicator testing
• Collaborative care – with other healthcare professionals when appropriate

questions.question: What Training Does a Chiropractor Have?
questions.answer:
Doctors of Chiropractic (DC) earn their degrees after extensive education and training, which makes them experts in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of neuromusculoskeletal conditions.

In Quebec, chiropractors complete a 5-year doctoral program (245 university credits) at an accredited institution, similar to medical doctors (who complete 225 university credits).

The 4,969+ hours of coursework covers:
• Fundamental sciences: anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, pathology
• Clinical sciences: diagnosis, radiology, orthopedics, neurology
• Chiropractic sciences: spinal biomechanics, adjustment techniques, treatment protocols
• Complementary disciplines: nutrition, exercise therapy, rehabilitation
• Real patient experience from year one: students begin observing and assisting with patient care
• 18-month supervised clinical internship: the final stage involves providing treating to hundreds of patients under direct supervision of experienced chiropractors

questions.question: Is chiropractic care safe?
questions.answer:
Chiropractic care is one of the safest healthcare treatments available, with serious complications occurring in fewer than 1 in 1,000,000 treatments. Among the 9,000+ licensed practitioners across Canada, all with doctoral-level training and strict regulatory oversight, an estimated 30 million chiropractic treatments are delivered each year to 4.7 million Canadians — with an exceptional safety record.

The most common effects are mild and temporary:
• Slight soreness for 24–48 hours — similar to post-workout muscle fatigue
• Brief stiffness as your body adjusts to improved movement
• Temporary tiredness as your nervous system recalibrates

Risk of serious complications by treatment type:
• All surgeries: 1 in 8 patients experience complications
• NSAIDs (Advil, Tylenol, etc.): 1 in every 300 users is hospitalized annually
• Chiropractic adjustments: Fewer than 1 in 1,000,000 cases

questions.question: How effective is chiropractic care in Canada?
questions.answer:
Chiropractic care is safe, effective and widely used in Canada. Each year, nearly 5 million Canadians (about 1 in 7) see a chiropractor with 90% patient satisfaction rate—adding up to over 30 million chiropractic sessions annually across the country.

Chiropractic helps patients recover faster, avoid unnecessary medications or surgeries, and live pain-free—with millions of success stories every year.

• Faster Recovery
56% of chronic low-back pain patients improved after just one month of chiropractic care—vs. only 13% under family doctors alone.

• Better Work Outcomes
Injured workers who saw chiropractors returned to work 51% faster than those treated by medical doctors.

• Quality of Life
Nearly 70% of patients in integrated healthcare programs experienced meaningful improvements in pain, function, and well-being.

• Satisfaction
Over 93% of patients were satisfied with chiropractic care in collaborative clinical settings.

questions.question: What is Applied Kinesiology?
questions.answer: Applied Kinesiology (AK) was developed by Dr. George Goodheart in 1964. It combines principles from chiropractic, osteopathy, physiotherapy, nutrition, and manual therapy to help practitioners address stubborn, complex conditions.
